courses.title: Introduction to Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: An the introductory course to LMC, this course introduces students to key texts and modes of analysis associated with the study of literature, film, digital media, and communication.

courses.title: Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: This course introduces second-semester majors to the intellectual movements, interpretive frameworks, and research skills central to the disciplines represented in LMC.

courses.title: Introduction to Literary Studies
courses.description: Students will study literary and cultural texts, methods, and critical movements from a variety of perspectives and historical periods.

courses.title: Introduction to Science, Technology and Culture
courses.description: Relation to other courses, programs and curricula: As the introductory course to the LMC Science, Technology and Culture thread, this course explores the way in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

courses.title: Introduction to Gender Studies
courses.description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender, examining topics such as biology and gender, social constructions of gender, and the psychology of sexual roles.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Justice
courses.description: Introduces students to the work and theory of social justice through readings from various disciplines, including literature, history, anthropology, philosophy, science, policy, and law.

courses.title: Introduction to Media Studies
courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print, radio, television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

courses.title: Introduction to Game Studies
courses.description: Introduction to the games studies and game designs.

courses.title: Introduction to Black Media Studies
courses.description: Introduces scholarship in Black Media Studies (BMS), which studies the relationships among media, culture, and racial politics by and about people of African descent.

courses.title: Introduction to Film
courses.description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots, scenes, and films.

courses.title: LMC 2500 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Introduction to Film.

courses.title: Introduction to Performance Studies
courses.description: An examination of the origins of the field of performance studies in literary study of theatre and drama, anthropological investigations of ritual, and sociological analyses of performance in everyday life.

courses.title: Theatre Production I
courses.description: In this hands-on course, students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

courses.title: Theatre Production II
courses.description: In this hands-on course, students create the lighting, property, and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Media
courses.description: Introduction to key concepts, methods, and achievements in computational media, and the convergence of digital technology with cultural traditions of representation.

courses.title: Principles of Visual Design
courses.description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

courses.title: Constructing the Moving Image
courses.description: Provides the student with the conceptual, formal, aesthetic, and technical approaches to reconsider film, videos, and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

courses.title: Special Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

courses.title: Film Acting Workshop
courses.description: A workshop-based introduction to screen acting and the acting profession for the student who is interested in participating in the film and television industries.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and the Classical Tradition
courses.description: Explores the definition and transmission of science and technology within Greek, Arabic, and medieval Latin contexts.

courses.title: The Age of Scientific Discovery
courses.description: Examines the relationships among texts representing the literary, artistic, and scientific thought of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

courses.title: The Age of Scientific Revolution
courses.description: Examines interrelation of technological, literary, artistic, and philosophical thought in the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

courses.title: Evolution and the Industrial Age
courses.description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries, particularly theories of evolution, to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

courses.title: Studies in Fiction
courses.description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction, especially the novel, distinctive, popular, and enduring. Readings may include formal, cultural, and historical theories.

courses.title: Poetry and Poetics
courses.description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

courses.title: Communication & Culture
courses.description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

courses.title: African American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Explores the works of African American writers from the Colonial period to the present and examines a variety of cultural constructs that have fundamentally shaped the African American literary tradition.

courses.title: Asian American Literature & Culture
courses.description: Explores Asian American literary and cultural contributions since the nineteenth century through the lens of migration histories and global events foundational to Asian American experience.

courses.title: Ethnicity in American Culture
courses.description: Explores literary and historical works considering ethnic issues in American culture, including immigration, social assimilation, "double consciousness", the development of ethnic identity/pride, and multiculturalism.

courses.title: Women, Literature, and Culture
courses.description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

courses.title: Science Fiction
courses.description: Examines science fiction texts from the last 200 years to show how they reflect ambigous reactions to change.

courses.title: Science Fiction Film and Television
courses.description: This course investigates science fiction as the genre developed during film history and has become one of the most popular forms of television narrative.

courses.title: LMC 3215 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Science Fiction Film & Television.

courses.title: Literature and Medicine
courses.description: This course examines works of literature dealing overtly with illness and healing, works about or by physicians and other caregivers, and works that raise questions about ethical behavior in the face of sickness.

courses.title: Gender Studies in the Disciplines
courses.description: This course explores the concept of gender and its usefulness as a theoretical category in a variety of disciplines. It includes cultural studies of literature, communication media, cultural anthropology, sociology, history, and science.

courses.title: Major Authors
courses.description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

courses.title: Shakespeare
courses.description: An examination of Shakespeare's works with attention to generic conventions, historical context, and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeare's contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

courses.title: Creative Writing
courses.description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres, and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

courses.title: Writing for the Stage and Screen
courses.description: Basic principles of generating creative concepts, dramatic structure, character and dialogue development, and formatting for stage and screenplays.

courses.title: Studies in Film and Television
courses.description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship, genre history, spectatorship, ideology, narrative theory, and the relationship between these media and social history.

courses.title: LMC 3252 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Studies in Film & Television.

courses.title: Animation
courses.description: This course examines animation from its earliest days as a "cinema of attractions' to its current development as a predominantly digital practice.

courses.title: LMC 3253 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Animation.

courses.title: Film History
courses.description: Surveys the history of film from its machine origins to its present digital developments. It focuses on various movements, figures, and narrative developments in world cinema.

courses.title: LMC 3254 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Film History.

courses.title: Cinema and Digital Culture
courses.description: This course examines the impact of digital technologies on contemporary cinema as well as the influence of different cinematic traditions on new digital media.

courses.title: LMC 3255 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Cinema and Digital Culture.

courses.title: Major Filmmakers
courses.description: Traces in depth an individual artist's career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

courses.title: LMC 3256 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Major Filmmakers.

courses.title: Global Cinema
courses.description: This course examines selected movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, emphasizing how contemporary film's global nature affects cultural representation.

courses.title: LMC 3257 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Global Cinema.

courses.title: Documentary Film
courses.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in fact-based film, emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

courses.title: LMC 3258 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Documentary Film.

courses.title: Experimental Film
courses.description: This course examines the history and trends in experimental film and video, emphasizing the relationship to avant-garde art movements.

courses.title: LMC 3259 Recitation
courses.description: Experimental Film—Recitation.

courses.title: Performance Studies
courses.description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

courses.title: Music, Culture, and Society
courses.description: Origins and development of contemporary popular music, including rock, trap, hip-hop, and other emerging and established forms.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Ideology
courses.description: Examines specific scientific, philosophical, and literary/cultural texts in order to determine the role ideology plays in the construction of culture, especially scientific and technological culture.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Gender
courses.description: Examines specific philosophical, scientific, and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge, currently and historically.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Race
courses.description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race, within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by "race" in scientific and technological culture.

courses.title: Environmentalism and Ecocriticism
courses.description: Surveys the emergence of ecocriticism as an analytical framework for interpreting the verbal and visual rhetorics of environmentalism in both western and nonwestern cultures.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Scientific Inquiry
courses.description: This course takes as its subject the ways in which argumentative and persuasive discourse is used to create and disseminate scientific knowledge.

courses.title: Technologies of Representation
courses.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues related by technologies of representation, including written, spoken, and gestural languages; print, painting and illustration; still and moving photography; recorded sound; and computer mediated communications and interactive digital media.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Postcolonialism
courses.description: Studies in the development of Postcolonial literary theory and historiography in order to analyze the interdependent discourses and practices of post-Enlightenment science/technology and European imperialism.

courses.title: Biomedicine and Culture
courses.description: Discuss the history of biology and medicine; popular representations of health, disease, and the medical establishment; and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

courses.title: Film and/as Technology
courses.description: Examines the development of film technology and the implications of that technology for cinema's treatment of technology.

courses.title: LMC 3352 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Film And/As Technology.

courses.title: Graphic and Visual Design
courses.description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic and visual design of print and digital media. Familiarity with use of the World Wide Web, page layout, and computer graphic software recommended.

courses.title: Technical Communication, Theory and Practice
courses.description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development.

courses.title: Social Media
courses.description: Students learn the cultural history, theory, and practice of social media in a variety of settings, and its impact on personal, professional, and political life.

courses.title: Media, Culture, and Society
courses.description: Examines the transformative impact of various kinds of media on culture, politics, communication, and education.

courses.title: Video Production
courses.description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding, scripting, filming, editing, and sound.

courses.title: Advanced Video Production
courses.description: This production course teaches students to create visually compelling and emotionally powerful images through shot design and the use of lights, cameras and prime lenses.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Technical Narratives
courses.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by such narrative documents as technical proposals, recommendations reports, grant proposals, and marketing studies. Emphasis on document design, graphics, navigation systems, and editing.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Nonlinear Documents
courses.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by hypertext documents. Emphasis in designing for multiple audiences, page and document design, and navigation in a nonlinear environment.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Visual Communication
courses.description: Focuses on contexts, audiences, arguements, and design in creating and critiquing visuals. Emphasizes topics such as information design, technical visuals, and photography.

courses.title: Communicating Science and Technology to the Public
courses.description: Examines both the theoretical and practical issues involved in communicating scientific and/or technological material to a variety of lay audiences.

courses.title: Content Strategy
courses.description: Theory and professional communication practice of substance, workflow, structure, and governance of digital content for websites and social media.

courses.title: Technical Communication Approaches
courses.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

courses.title: Technical Communication Strategies
courses.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

courses.title: Blackness, Media, and Meaning-Making
courses.description: Considers the significance of Blackness in print, broadcast, and digital media.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Digital Media
courses.description: Explores issues of race, ethnicity, and gender + the politics of technology (technoculture) in digital venues, social media, artificial intelligence, algorithms, and mundane digital phenomena.

courses.title: Introduction to Black Cultural Production
courses.description: Examines the communicative and cultural practices of Black mediated narratives across the Diaspora.

courses.title: Afrofuturism
courses.description: Students study Black cultural producers melding art and technology in science fiction and fantasy that reflect the complicated politics of envisioning the future.

courses.title: Producing Black Documentary Film and Podcasts
courses.description: Connects building healthy Black communities and Black economic empowerment within the framework of contemporary documentary filmmaking. Students will write, produce, edit, and distribute a mini-documentary.

courses.title: Major Topics in Black Media Studies
courses.description:
Surveys the origins, development, and considers conventions through an investigation of major topics 
of black media and music.

courses.title: Technoculture
courses.description: Grounded in a critical race and cultural theoretic framework, the course explores systems and practices of scientific inquiry as mediated by Whiteness, imperialism, and modernity.

courses.title: Black Cultural Politics and the Southern Experience
courses.description: Investigate racial politics, social justice, and technocultural innovation across  Atlanta and the American South.

courses.title: Afrofuturism and the Anthropocene
courses.description: Explores history and current status of Afrofuturism, a cultural movement, an epistemology, and an aesthetic centering Blackness and technology with visions for the future considering the Anthropocene.

courses.title: Ancient and Medieval Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Greece, Rome, and Medieval Europe through an examination of one or a few major culture conflicts expressed in the literary genres and periods.

courses.title: Renaissance Literature and Culture
courses.description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

courses.title: Enlightenment and Culture
courses.description: Examines the nature of the age from an intial boldness, optimism, and faith in reason to a recognition of its limits.

courses.title: American Literature & Culture
courses.description: Introduces students to American literature and culture broadly construed, examining foundational works of critical and historical significance.

courses.title: British and Continental Romanticism
courses.description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

courses.title: Victorian Literature and Culture
courses.description: Investigates the period 1830 - 1901 in English literature and culture, focusing on how that period defined key questions, especially ones about human nature, society, and the relation of religion to science.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Modernism
courses.description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Postmodernism
courses.description: A survey of major themes, representational techniques, and social and cultural concerns of postmodern art and literature.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Literature & Culture
courses.description: This course will cover a range of possible critical areas of global concern in contemporary literature and culture. Focus will vary each semester.

courses.title: Theatre Production III: Management
courses.description: In this "hands-on" course, students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

courses.title: Theatre Production IV: Acting
courses.description: This course providess students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

courses.title: Principles of Information Design
courses.description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

courses.title: Principles of Interaction Design
courses.description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments, emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.title: Senior Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: Capstone seminar that asks majors to draw upon their training to engage in closer analysis, research, and/or production in topical area. Topic varies by instructor.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.description: Preparation for and writing of a thesis through faculty-directed independent study.

courses.title: Poetry and Poetics II
courses.description: Advanced study of the traditions of poetic theory and practice with a special emphasis on processes of poetic conception and revision.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Professional Communication
courses.description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication, this course will alternate among a number of issues including property law, integrating print and electronic media, and cultural studies of corporate environments.

courses.title: Video Editing and Postproduction
courses.description: Introduction to Editing and Post Production develops the skills and knowledge of digital film post-production, concentrating on editing, editing theory, narrative editing, and post-production workflow.

courses.title: Seminar in Film Studies
courses.description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement, theory, period, or technological development in film studies.

courses.title: LMC 4500 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Seminar in Film.

courses.title: Performance Practicum
courses.description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting, directing, designing, playwriting, performance art, performance and new media.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Proposal Writing
courses.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Thesis Writing
courses.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their undergraduate thesis.

courses.title: Game Studio
courses.description: Project-based course in designing and implementing video games.

courses.title: Interactive Narrative
courses.description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre, including its roots ini experimental uses of older media, and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

courses.title: Games Design as a Cultural Practice
courses.description: Emphasis is on the design elements common to games and the expressive possibilities and cultural concerns specific to digital games.

courses.title: Experimental Digital Art
courses.description: Provides students with key conceptual, formal, aesthetic and technical elements needed in creating artifacts in areas ranging from augmented and mixed reality to scientific visualization.

courses.title: Game AI
courses.description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: Project-based course in designing implementing experiences using the technologies of Augmented, Mixed, and Virtual Reality. Credit not awarded for both LMC 4733 and CS 4770/6770/LMC 6340.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STAC classes.

courses.title: Edu Applications New
courses.description: This course introduces students to a variety of perspectives on learning as they apply to work in educational technology. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6213 and LCC 6213.

courses.title: Issues in Media Studies
courses.description: This course focuses on the study of mass media from historical, theoretical, and cultural perspectives. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6215 and LCC 6215.

courses.title: The Computer as an "Expressive Medium"
courses.description: Explores the development of the representational power of the computer and the interplay between digital technology and culture. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6310 and LCC 6310.

courses.title: Visual Culture and Design
courses.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6311 and LCC 6311.

courses.title: Design, Technology & Representation
courses.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation through critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6312 and LCC 6312.

courses.title: Principles of Interaction Design
courses.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6313 and LCC 6313.

courses.title: Design of Networked Media
courses.description: Issues in hypertextual and multimedia design in networked environments, including the World Wide Web, interactive television, and wireless applications. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6314 and LCC 6314.

courses.title: Product Production
courses.description: Focuses on defining user and client needs, analysis of competing products, budgeting, scheduling and management of the production process, and the design of the testing process. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6315 and LCC 6315.

courses.title: Historical Approaches to Digital Media
courses.description: Examines digital media in the context of earlier media, such as handwriting and printing as well as photography, radio, film, and television. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6316 and LCC 6316.

courses.title: Interactive Narrative/Fiction
courses.description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds, interactive characters, simulations, and replay worlds. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6317 and LCC 6317, LMC 6317 and LCC 4720, or LMC 6317 and LMC 4720.

courses.title: Experimental Media
courses.description: Students will develop the critical, intellectual, and creative tools necessary to understand, work with, and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6318 and LCC 6318.

courses.title: Intellectual Property Policy and Law
courses.description: Students examine constitutionally informed policy and pragmatic legal issues in intellectual property law, focusing on the effects of power structures and information digitization. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6319 and LCC 6319.

courses.title: Globalization and New Media
courses.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6320 and LCC 6320.

courses.title: Architecture of Responsive Spaces
courses.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6321 and LCC 6321.

courses.title: Global Intellectual Property Policy and Law
courses.description: This course requires that students gain facility with intellectual property statutory and treaty law and understand US and global policies that affect power and access.

courses.title: Game Design and Analysis
courses.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including issues of creation, and reception, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6325 and LCC 6325, LMC 6325 and LCC 4725, or LMC 6325 and LMC 4725.

courses.title: Expressive Virtual Space
courses.description: Practical and theoretical investigation of virtual space in real-time 3D environments with a focus on meditation and functionality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6330 and LCC 6330.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality, Tangible Computing, or other forms of Mixed Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6340 and LCC 6340/LMC 4733/CS 6770/4770.

courses.title: The spatial construction of meaning: Design formulation and design cognition
courses.description: Study of the way in which space is manipulated to construct meaning in design formulation. Emphasis on logical structure, geometry, and experiential correlates. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6350 and LCC 6350.

courses.title: Global Ethnographies and Communication Practices
courses.description: This course employs ethnographic methods to examine how the creation of visual, textual and digita; artifacts can be understood as practices of intercultural communication.

courses.title: Transnational Networks
courses.description: In this course, we will look at the historical and theoretical implications of the networked construction of the Atlantic World, and the legacies it has left for contemporary global protest and liberation movements.

courses.title: Cultures of Empire
courses.description: This course focuses upon empires of the nineteenth-century and contemporary post-colonial responses to European colonization. Central issues include immigration, globalization, nationalism, imperial subjectivity, and belonging.

courses.title: Global Science Fiction
courses.description: Explores how authors and critics across the globe use science fiction to communicate experiences with science and technology across centuries, continents, and cultures.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Theory
courses.description: Concentration on a single literary or cultural theorist and/or major school of literary or cultural theory, including, among others, Materialist, Feminist, Structuralist, Post-Structuralistm Cultural Studies.

courses.title: Global Cinema
courses.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, with an emphasis on how the global nature of contemporary film affects cultural representation.

courses.title: Discovery & Invention
courses.description: Required course for all DM majors. The purpose of this course is to give students a suite of methods they can use in professional settings to discover opportunities for inventive new computational products and services. It complements the design and production skills developed in 6310 and 6313 with applied research skills. For students in the MS DM and MS HCI programs it will also help them in the development of their MS proposals. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6399 and LCC 6399.

courses.title: Project Studio
courses.description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media(NM) Center.

courses.title: STS Core Seminar
courses.description: This survey course covers key works Science, Technology & Society, and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6743 and LCC 6743, LMC 6743 and HTS 6743, or LMC 6743 and PUBP 6743.

courses.title: Social Justice, Critical Theory, and Philosophy of Design
courses.description: Focuses on social justice from a Science, Technology, and Society(STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6748 and LCC 6748 or LMC 6748 and PUBP 6748.

courses.title: Feminist Theory and STS
courses.description: This course is an advanced science, technology and society (STS) seminar in feminist theory. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6749 and LCC 6749 or LMC 6749 and PUBP 6749.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction Professional Preparation and Practice
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to mixed reality design and prototyping with a focus on Augmented Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6770 and CS 4770.

courses.title: Digital Media Master's Project
courses.description: Final project course in Digital Media.

courses.title: HCI Master's Project
courses.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digital Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

courses.title: Digital Media Master's Thesis
courses.description: Final Thesis course in Digital Media.

courses.title: PhD Qualifying Prep
courses.description: Preparation for Ph.D. Qualifying exam.

courses.title: Proseminar in Media Theory
courses.description: Key traditions of media theory that contribute to the study of Digital Media. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8000 and LCC 8000.

courses.title: Proseminar in Digital Media Studies
courses.description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8001 and LCC 8001.

courses.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.description: Special Topics in Digital Media.

courses.description: Advanced Issues in Interactive Narrative.

courses.title: Special Topics in Game Design and Analysis
courses.description: Advanced topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including creation, reception, procedural technique, and tradition.

courses.title: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation
courses.description: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation.

courses.title: Special Problems in Human-Computer Interaction
courses.description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems in Information Design and Technology
courses.description: An independent study course.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.
